keyTakeAways: Cold water does not enhance hair shine; warm water is preferable to avoid dehydration.
Split ends cannot be repaired and require a haircut as the only solution; products only provide temporary cosmetic fixes.
Hair growth speed cannot be increased by cutting hair or using products; such claims are false.
Regular washing is essential to prevent scalp buildup, dandruff, and yeast-related issues due to oil accumulation.
Dry shampoo is safe when used sparingly but can lead to scalp issues if overused without washing.
Sulfate-free shampoos may be beneficial for drier hair types to preserve natural oils.
Haircare should be approached like skincare — removing product buildup is essential to maintain scalp health.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article debunks four common haircare myths: cold water does not enhance shine, split ends cannot be repaired, hair growth cannot be accelerated by cutting, and infrequent washing leads to scalp problems. Experts Eva Proudman and Tracey Walker, along with Professor Laura Waters, emphasize that healthy hair depends on proper scalp care, balanced water temperatures, and avoiding over-reliance on products that offer false solutions. The article promotes simple, evidence-based practices such as washing every other day for oily hair, using sulfate-free shampoos for dry hair, and using dry shampoo only occasionally to maintain scalp health.
title: Can shampoo repair hair? Four haircare myths get the chop
